title: Housing NZ state house increase 'smoke and mirrors' - Labour
text:
Housing NZ state house increase 'smoke and mirrors' - Labour SAM SACHDEVA Last updated 13:22, February 8 2017 SCOTT HAMMOND/FAIRFAX NZ 
Housing NZ has revealed its building programme will create a net increase of only 722 houses over the next three years. 
Housing NZ has revealed it will only add an extra 722 state houses in Auckland over the next three years, leading Labour to accuse the Government of "smoke and mirrors" over its promises to address the housing crisis. 
In October last year, Prime Minister Bill English - the Housing NZ minister at the time - said the Government was preparing to build tens of thousands of houses in Auckland to help ease pressure on the housing market. 
Earlier in the year, English confirmed Housing NZ would not have to pay a dividend, as it required the money to ramp up its own building programme. CHARLOTTE CURD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Labour housing spokesman Phil Tywford has accused the Government of "smoke and mirrors" over its work with Housing NZ to ease an Auckland shortage. 
Speaking to Parliament's social services committee on Wednesday, Housing NZ chief executive Andrew McKenzie said the Crown agency intended to build 4900 new homes in Auckland over the next three years. 
READ MORE: 
However, when the demolition of existing state houses was taken into account, McKenzie said there would only be a net increase of 722 houses - just over 240 each year. SUPPLIED 
Bill English is being criticised for his government's response to the housing crisis. 
The small net increase was due to the time it took to move people out of old houses into a new property, then demolish the property and create space to "build up and out", he said. 
"We're at a phase where we need to create capacity to be able to utilise the land better ... to move our tenants into the new homes, free up the new land, [and] the numbers obviously accelerate after that." 
Housing NZ board chairwoman Adrienne Young-Cooper defended the agency's performance, saying while it had missed an "aspirational target" to build 2000 houses over the two years to December 2015, it had met its official performance requirements. 
"In this financial year we have quite ambitious targets, and we're on programme to deliver those - they're in excess of what we did in the year under review." Ad Feedback 
The organisation was "going through a significant capacity build" to ensure it could ramp up construction, Young-Cooper said. 
Labour housing spokesman Phil Twyford said Housing NZ's admission showed the Government's housing promises were "smoke and mirrors", with the 722-house net increase only a quarter of the current Auckland state house waiting list of 2654 families. 
"When Bill English promised 30,000 new homes to be built on state housing land, what he failed to say was that National will barely increase Auckland's state housing stock at all, despite a burgeoning population and a chronic housing crisis. 
"Families are living in cars and garages, and the best National can do is add an extra 240-odd state houses in Auckland per year." - Stuff
